name: Spiroperone
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-4583
Reason: 1,1'-Spiro-2-benzopyran has a melting point of 100 degrees Celsius. The basic unit for our comparison will be benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C (according to the CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics, 49th Edition, 1968-1969). The structural modifications we need to consider are the presence of two additional phenyl rings. Phenyl groups, when connected to a benzene ring, tend to increase the melting point due to the enhancement of the crystalline structure and the increase in molecular weight. In the case of Spiroperone, we have two additional phenyl rings linked in a linear fashion, which would notably augment the melting point. Each additional phenyl group can be estimated to add approximately 100°C to the melting point due to increased pi-pi interactions, rigidity, and molecular weight. Additionally, the Spiro-2-benzopyran structure introduces a rigid ring system with increased molecular weight, contributing approximately +20°C. The ketone group introduces polar carbonyl interactions, contributing approximately +40°C. The methoxy group introduces additional rigidity and possible hydrogen bonding, raising the melting point by approximately +5°C. The presence of two additional phenyl rings linked in a linear fashion significantly increases the melting point due to the enhancement of the crystalline structure and the increase in molecular weight. Each additional phenyl group can be estimated to add approximately 100°C to the melting point due to increased pi-pi interactions, rigidity, and molecular weight.
